Preamble.origin: [Middle French preambule , from Medieval Latin preambulum , from Late Latin, neuter of preambulus walking in front of, from Latin prae- + ambulare to walk]

1.1: an introductory statement (as to a contract)

2.1: the introductory part of a constitution or statute that usually states the reasons for and intent of the law
2.note: While preambles do not state law and therefore are not judicially enforceable, they are used to determine legislative intent when interpreting statutes.
